key_title: Key to the species of Cyperus

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Cyperaceae

source.author: Wilson, K.L.
source.title: Cyperaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Wilson, K.L. (1994). Cyperaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Style 3-fid; nut ± trigonous
Style 2-fid; nut lenticular, biconvex, plano-or concavo-convex
Dwarf annuals, curry-scented (at least when dried)
Annuals or perennials but not curry-scented
Spikelets ± angular, with glumes arranged spirally; nut c. two-thirds as long as glume
Spikelets flattened, with glumes arranged distichously; nut from one-third to two-thirds as long as glume
Spikelets arranged spicately along the rachis of the ultimate branches of the inflorescence, in the form of very short to elongated spikes

Spikelets digitately or subdigitately clustered, in clusters sometimes dense on a much reduced rachis, sometimes very few in number or solitary and then often appearing lateral when the lowest bract is erect
Rachilla of the spikelet distinctly winged, the wings sometimes falling later
Rachilla not winged or with very narrow wings
Spikelets fewer than 20 per spike
Spikelets usually more than 20 per spike, numerous to very numerous

Glumes remote (i.e. with glumes not or scarcely overlapping the glume immediately above on the same side of the rachilla); spikelets 1–1.5 mm diam., flattened to terete; rhizome, if present, not tuber-bearing

Glumes overlapping at least one-quarter of the length of the glume immediately above on the same side of the rachilla; spikelets more than 1.5 mm wide in side view, ± flattened; plants with tuber-bearing rhizomes

Culms terete below, trigonous near the apex; leaves rarely half as long as culms; lowest involucral bract erect, very much exceeding the inflorescence, usually pushing it to one side; nut when mature 2–3 times as long as broad; freely fruiting

Culms trigonous or triquetrous throughout their length; leaves mostly from one-half to three-quarters as long as culms; inflorescence symmetrical; nut either c. 1.5 times as long as broad or rarely maturing

Glumes yellow to dark golden brown, 3-nerved on each side; spikelets more or less parallel-sided and with obtuse apex, mostly 5–15 mm long; rachis of spikes mostly finely hispid; tubers globose to ovoid, with fine greyish tomentum at maturity; rhizomes yellow-brown

Glumes pale red-brown to orange-brown or very dark red-brown, 1–3-nerved on each side; spikelets tapering gradually to an acute apex, mostly 15–30 mm long; rachis of spikes glabrous or rarely finely hispid; tubers ± ellipsoid, without tomentum; rhizomes purplish to dark brown

Lowest 1 or 2 involucral bracts much exceeding inflorescence; spikelets 2.5–3 mm wide in side view when mature; glumes very pale red-brown to red- or orange-brown, rarely very dark, midrib straight in side view from immediately above the base to apex; nut c. 1.5 times as long as broad, broad-obovoid; nuts freely produced; fibrous coats of tubers often persisting into the second year

Lowest 2–4 involucral bracts shorter or not much longer than inflorescence; spikelets 1.5–2.5 mm wide when mature; glumes usually dark red-brown, midrib faintly curved and recurved in side view from base to apex; nuts rarely maturing (2–3 times as long as broad if present, narrow-obovoid to ellipsoid); fibrous coats of tubers soon disintegrating, not usually persisting beyond the first year
Glumes 1–1.5 mm long
Glumes 2–6.5 mm long
Leaves not septate-nodulose; tufted perennial, often apparently annual, often without any rhizome
Leaves and bracts septate-nodulose when dried; robust, tussock-forming perennials
Glumes 2–2.5 mm long
Glumes 4–6.5 mm long
Leaves and bracts thin, flat or with revolute margins; lowest involucral bracts spreading; tufted perennial, often apparently annual and without a rhizome
Leaves and bracts leathery, flat or folded, margins and midribs scabrous; perennials, either long-rhizomatous with culms solitary, or robust and tussock-forming
Glumes obtuse in side view but sometimes apparently acute because of the presence of a short mucro; glumes 1.5–2.5 mm long; robust, tussock-forming perennial
Glumes ± acute in side view; glumes 2.5–4 mm long; slender rhizomatous perennial with solitary culms
Elongated involucral bracts 6–22
Elongated involucral bracts 1–5
Leaves reduced to sheaths
Leaves with well-developed blades

Glumes remote (i.e. with glumes not or scarcely overlapping the glume immediately above on the same side of the rachilla); spikelets 1–1.5 mm diam., flattened to terete; rhizome, if present, not tuber-bearing

Glumes overlapping at least one-quarter of the length of the glume immediately above on the same side of the rachilla; spikelets more than 1.5 mm wide in side view, ± flattened; plants with tuber-bearing rhizomes

Culms terete below, trigonous near the apex; leaves rarely half as long as culms; lowest involucral bract erect, very much exceeding the inflorescence, usually pushing it to one side; nut when mature 2–3 times as long as broad; freely fruiting

Culms trigonous or triquetrous throughout their length; leaves mostly from one-half to three-quarters as long as culms; inflorescence symmetrical; nut either c. 1.5 times as long as broad or rarely maturing

Glumes yellow to dark golden brown, 3-nerved on each side; spikelets more or less parallel-sided and with obtuse apex, mostly 5–15 mm long; rachis of spikes mostly finely hispid; tubers globose to ovoid, with fine greyish tomentum at maturity; rhizomes yellow-brown

Glumes pale red-brown to orange-brown or very dark red-brown, 1–3-nerved on each side; spikelets tapering gradually to an acute apex, mostly 15–30 mm long; rachis of spikes glabrous or rarely finely hispid; tubers ± ellipsoid, without tomentum; rhizomes purplish to dark brown

Lowest 1 or 2 involucral bracts much exceeding inflorescence; spikelets 2.5–3 mm wide in side view when mature; glumes very pale red-brown to red- or orange-brown, rarely very dark, midrib straight in side view from immediately above the base to apex; nut c. 1.5 times as long as broad, broad-obovoid; nuts freely produced; fibrous coats of tubers often persisting into the second year

Lowest 2–4 involucral bracts shorter or not much longer than inflorescence; spikelets 1.5–2.5 mm wide when mature; glumes usually dark red-brown, midrib faintly curved and recurved in side view from base to apex; nuts rarely maturing (2–3 times as long as broad if present, narrow-obovoid to ellipsoid); fibrous coats of tubers soon disintegrating, not usually persisting beyond the first year
Leaves all or mostly reduced to sheaths
Leaves with well-developed blades

Involucral bracts 2–4, usually less than 5 cm long, very rigid and pungent with incurved margins; inflorescence head-like or with 1–3 short branches to 2 cm long, bearing globose clusters of spikelets

Involucral bracts mostly 5–8 in number, always more than 5 cm and up to 15 cm long, flat, firm-textured, not pungent; inflorescence simple to compound with 4–12 branches to 6 cm long, bearing hemispherical clusters of spikelets, or occasionally loosely head-like
Glumes less than 2 mm long (excluding any long mucro)
Glumes 2 mm long or more (excluding any long mucro)
Glumes with sides evenly red-brown to dark red-brown or blackish (keels mostly green)
Glumes uniformly green or with sides hyaline, white, pale brown, yellow or golden brown, occasionally with a red-brown patch (keels mostly green)
Rachilla winged
Rachilla not winged
Spikelets few (1–12) in the loose, ovoid to hemispherical clusters
Spikelets numerous in the dense globose clusters
Glumes 0.6–0.9 mm long
Glumes 1.5–2 mm long
Glumes with 1 nerve or no nerves on each side
Glumes with 2–5 nerves on each side
Involucral bracts 2–4, erect to spreading; inflorescence with 1–25 spikelets; small perennial or annual; spikelets 2.5–4 mm wide in side view; nut pale brown
Involucral bract 1, erect; inflorescence of 1–4 spikelets; dwarf annual
Glumes at maturity with sides uniformly yellow to red-brown
Glumes at maturity with sides uniformly green, whitish, pale brown, or with red-brown patches
Glumes with keel about as wide as sides and with cell outlines larger than on sides, 1-nerved only at edge of keel
Glumes with keel much narrower than sides and with cell outlines similar to those of sides, with 2–4 nerves on each side
Leaves and bracts strongly curly at least near apex
Leaves and bracts straight to slightly curved
Leaf-sheaths pale yellowish with red-brown blotches; nut colliculate to smooth
Leaf-sheaths pinkish to purple-red; nut tuberculate or colliculate

Glumes 3.5–4 mm long, 1- or 2-nerved  either side of the keel (rarely a 3rd weak nerve visible), the nerves occupying less than half the width of each side of the glume membranous margin wider than the

Glumes under 3 mm long, or if ever approaching 4 mm (C. lhotskyanus), then distinctly 2–4-nerved per side and the nerves occupying most of the width of each side of the more-or-less firm-textured glume
Prickles on leaf margins antrorsely aculeate, more or less regularly spaced
Prickles on leaf margins mixed aculeate to papillose, antrorse to erect or flabellate, more or less irregularly spaced
Anthers 0.3–1.2 mm long; tufted perennial; plants occasionally viscid
Anthers 1.3–2.0 mm long; rhizomatous perennial, with culms usually solitary along rhizome; plants never viscid
Spikelets less than 2.5 mm wide in side view
Spikelets 2.5–5 mm wide in side view
Inflorescence simple to compound, with 3–8 primary branches and numerous spikelets in dense clusters
Inflorescence a single cluster of 1–14 spikelets
Glumes with keel about as wide as sides and with cell outlines larger than on sides, nerved only at edge of keel; plants never viscid
Glumes with keel much narrower than sides and with cell outlines similar to those of sides, with 2–4 nerves on each side; plants occasionally viscid
Culms 25–50 cm long; leaves mostly septate-nodulose; leaf-sheaths pale yellowish or straw-coloured with occasional red-brown patches
Culms 3–25 cm long; leaves not septate-nodulose; leaf-sheaths pinkish to purple-red near base
Spikelets several- to numerous-flowered; rachilla continuous, persistent; glumes individually deciduous at maturity
Spikelets 1-flowered, but sometimes with a second imperfect flower above; whole spikelet falling as a unit at maturity
Inflorescence pseudolateral, sessile; lowest involucral bract erect, appearing as a continuation of the rush-like culm; probably not in Victoria, see note after genus description
Inflorescence obviously terminal, branched or head-like; involucral bracts not as above
Nut dorsally flattened with a flat or concave face against the rachilla; inflorescence densely head-like, subglobose, with 5–7 or more involucral bracts exceeding inflorescence
Nut laterally flattened, with one edge against the rachilla; inflorescence loosely head-like or branched, with 1–4 involucral bracts exceeding inflorescence
Glumes with straight to excurved mucro 0.3–0.7 mm long; glume spacing 0.5–0.8 mm
Glumes not or scarcely mucronate; glume spacing c. 1 mm
Glumes incurved dorsally in side view, dark red-brown to blackish, often with a hyaline patch on sides
Glumes ± straight dorsally in side view, yellow to very dark yellow-brown, occasionally red-brown but never with a hyaline patch
Spikelets spreading widely, in loose, shortly spicate to subdigitate clusters; rachilla not winged
Spikelets suberect, usually densely crowded in obconical subdigitate clusters; rachilla narrowly winged
Inflorescence ± ovoid, dense, solitary or with 2 smaller ones at the base; spikelets numerous, sometimes 100 in number, 1-flowered; keel of glumes usually toothed; stamen 1 (rarely 2 or 3)

Inflorescence globose, loose, always solitary; spikelets not usually more than 50, a second imperfect flower often present; keel of glumes usually smooth or nearly so, rarely toothed; stamens 3 (occasionally 2)
